headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Benjamin Sesko progress, Alejandro Garnacho update, Rasmus Hojlund future
body: Hello and welcome back to the Manchester United transfer blog on Thursday, July 31.

Those of you who decided to stay up overnight may well be feeling tired but shall be delighted with what you witnessed in Chicago. United continued their unbeaten start to pre-season with an exceptional 4-1 victory against AFC Bournemouth.

Rasmus Hojlund opened the scoring, before Patrick Dorgu, Amad and youngster Ethan Williams added gloss to the scoreline. The only blotch on the performance was an own goal from Matthijs de Ligt but it would do little to dampen the enthusiasm for that display.

Away from pre-season, United's main focus is now a move for RB Leipzig's Benjamin Sesko. The Reds are advancing their approach for the Slovenian after discovering that the pursuit of Ollie Watkins was unlikely to be fruitful.
The determination to sign Sesko has led to questions over Hojlund's future which Amorim addressed in Chicago overnight.
Take a look at all the United news, views and rumours in our dedicated blog below
According to Football Insider, United are looking into the possibility of selling players to the Saudi Pro League.
While no exact names have been mentioned in relation to being sold, Garnacho, Antony, Sancho and Malacia have all requested to leave Old Trafford.
The Middle East has become synonymous with big wages but now also big transfer fees with Chelsea banking £43.7m for Joao Felix.
One brief worry for United fans waking up this morning is that new signing Cunha was not in the squad that beat Bournemouth.
Fans will remember last summer that Leny Yoro picked up a severe injury during the pre-season tour of the US and United do not need history repeating itself.
Thankfully, Amorim explained Cunha's absence and it is nothing too serious.
MORE HERE
With the pursuit of Sesko now intensifying, that only adds to the speculation surrounding the future of Hojlund.
Since arriving at the club, the Dane has been the first choice centre-forward and whether his performances have merited that position or not is up for debate.
What isn't up for debate is that this move to try and sign Sesko will clearly lead Hojlund to question whether he is best sticking at United and fighting for his place, or moving elsewhere.
Yesterday, MEN Sport brought you the news that Benjamin Sesko was now United's top target in the summer transfer window.
United had been weighing up whether to target him over Ollie Watkins.
However, Villa are adamant that Watkins will be remaining at their club and thus United have decided to turn their attention to Sesko.
MORE HERE
Nicolas Jackson has flattered to deceive at Chelsea.
Last season, he averaged a goal every three Premier League matches which is hardly the sort of return that shall spark unparalleled excitement.
He is still at the early stages of his career but is two years older than Sesko.
In truth, choosing not to sign Jackson is perhaps no bad thing.
MEN Sport understands that United currently have no interest in swapping Garnacho with Chelsea's Nicolas Jackson.
Chelsea are thought to still be interested in a move for Garnacho.
However, there is no desire from the Reds to bring in Jackson as part of that deal.
MORE HERE
If he were to leave after suddenly becoming surplus to requirements, a move to Italy has been highly talked about.
Hojlund's standing in Serie A remains high after his performances for Atalanta.
Inter were credited with interest previously, as have Juventus as they look to replace Dusan Vlahovic.
From the end of last season, talk has been rife about the future of Hojlund with the striker asked on international duty if he was set to leave.
He replied then that his plan was to be at United this season and that was all he is focused on.
This stance has been reflected on the rumour mill too with journalist Fabrizio Romano among those to state that his preference is to remain at Old Trafford.
Speaking to the assembled media in the US, Ruben Amorim was unable to give any guarantees that Hojlund would be staying at United beyond this summer.
He explained:

I am really happy with Rasmus. I don't know what is going to happen until the end of the market. The important thing is that the strikers that are here are working really well, are improving, are helping the team and that is the most important thing. The important thing is that Rasmus is scoring goals. He's connecting really well with the team. He's improving. Again, I don't know what is going to happen until the market is closed.
MORE HERE
Hello and welcome to the United transfer blog this Thursday morning.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be taking you through until lunchtime with all the latest United news.
We shall start with reaction to the victory over Bournemouth where the latest on this man's future was discussed...
RB Leipzig are demanding a fee of £64million plus add-ons as well as a sell-on percentage for a deal for Benjamin Sesko, as per The Athletic.
Manchester United have made Sesko their first-choice striker option and want to agree a deal for the Slovenian before the end of the summer transfer window.
Barcelona head coach Hansi Flick has admitted he has been monitoring Marcus Rashford's career for some time now, following his summer loan move from Manchester United.

Speaking in a press conference on Wednesday, Flick said: "Rashford? I've been following him for many years, ever since he started his career at Man United. We hope he can show his quality this season."
Speaking to Boyle Sports, Louis Saha has urged former club Manchester United to make a move for Aston Villa goalkeeper Emiliano Martinez this summer.
Emiliano Martinez is a winner, he's a leader, he's got character. He will definitely provide this kind of balance that sometimes Andre Onana didn’t show last season.
Yes, he's a confident goalkeeper, Onana, but he made too many mistakes. It doesn't mean that Emiliano is not going to make any mistakes because that position is very fragile.

Last year, I have never seen any goalkeeper go through that at Manchester United or at any of the big clubs, it was horrific to see and I'm sure that he understands what people were saying. I think the competition is going to be healthy.
He needs to realise for his career that he needs to do better and that those types of performance are almost unacceptable.
Manchester United remain interested in signing a goalkeeper and made an enquiry about Paris Saint-Germain No.1 Gianluigi Donnarumma earlier in the summer, according to The Telegraph.
PSG are in the process of signing Lucas Chevalier from Lille and the Ligue 1 side are believed to be braced for United renewing their interest in Donnarumma once that deal is complete.
Chelsea are still pushing to sign Manchester United forward Alejandro Garnacho this summer, talkSPORT understands.
Garnacho, 21, is keen on the move to Stamford Bridge but United are pushing for a deal of at least £40million.
The Argentine has long looked destined to leave United in this transfer window, with the Reds keen to offload him.
Manchester United head of scouting Christopher Vivell appears to be pushing the club's move for Benjamin Sesko, according to Sky Sport Germany.
It's claimed that Vivell is 'very eager' to bring Sesko, 22, to Manchester this summer, after Ruben Amorim wanted Aston Villa's Ollie Watkins instead.
United have already held talks with Sesko's camp and there is a feeling at Leipzig that Sesko would choose the Reds ahead of Newcastle United and other alternatives.
Saudi Pro League side Al-Nassr have made a bid to sign Antony from Manchester United, according to Foot Mercato.

The 25-year-old, who scored nine times and provided five assists in 26 appearances during a successful loan spell at Real Betis last season, is expected to leave United on a permanent deal this summer.
Betis are keen to re-sign the Brazilian and Atletico Madrid have expressed an interest, but it's Al-Nassr who have made the latest move to secure his services.
It's unclear how much the Saudi outfit have offered, but Antony could reunite with former United teammate Cristiano Ronaldo in the Middle East.
According to talkSPORT, Nick Pope may end up on United's radar after Newcastle moved to add a new shot stopper on Tuesday.
It is understood a deal has been reached for Newcastle to loan Southampton's Aaron Ramsdale this season.
With Ramsdale arriving, Newcastle will likely need to part ways with a goalkeeper of their own and Pope may well be available on loan for United who have a limited budget for a new goalkeeper.
He explained:

It seems now that Amorim is identifying the players that he does not want in the squad - that's a positive. I do like, on paper, the signings of Cunha and Mbeumo. Why do I like them? A couple of reasons, well three actually. One, they have got Premier League experience. They look more like the United style of players, a bit more pace and power, and the ability to have that physicality to get from box-to-box. When you look at Garnacho, Sancho and Antony they are more 'jinkers'. I have always thought at United you need players who can open their legs up and sort of stretch teams - Cunha and Mbeumo do that. And the other thing I like is that they have not proved themselves at the highest level yet - in the Premier League or European level - so they should be desperate and hungry to play on a huge stage like Old Trafford. And that hunger has not always been there in the last ten years.
Further to the news that United are advancing on a move for Sesko, his agent has always kept the door open for him in the north west.
Despite rejecting the Reds in favour of RB Leipzig three years ago, Sesko's agent Elvis Basanovic has regularly attended Carrington.
United did enquire about Gyokeres this summer but he had his heart set on a move to Arsenal who were also thought to be keen on Sesko earlier in the window.
United are advancing with a potential move for RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko.
Villa remain adamant Ollie Watkins is not for sale and United have received encouragement to pursue Sesko instead.
Sesko, 22, is actually younger than United's current number nine, Rasmus Hojlund, and the Slovenia international has scored a modest 27 goals in 64 Bundesliga games.
MORE HERE
If Sesko has indeed decided that United is going to be his next club and the recruitment team are making him their priority, that is huge news for the Reds.
There was a concern that United may struggle to lure the players they needed to Old Trafford without Champions League football.
And yet, time and time again, the lure of United seems to be working as strong as ever before.
It appears that the move for Sesko this summer is starting to take shape.
Now, The Athletic's David Ornstein understands that United are now in favour of signing the Slovenian if they are to bring a striker to the club this summer.
United are understood to be unwilling to spend what they believe Villa would want to bring Watkins to Old Trafford so their focus is now Sesko.
It is thought that RB Leipzig will be looking for between £69m and £78m for the striker.
Following on from the report that Sesko prefers a move to United, the Daily Mail understands that Newcastle are beginning to accept they wont sign the forward.
It is claimed that there is a feeling in the north east that United will complete a deal for the Slovenian.
They do add that this could mean the door opens for their own move for Watkins this summer.
According to former footballer turned journalist Jan Aage Fjortoft, Sesko has decided on his next club.
Thankfully for Reds fans, it is good news as it appears the Slovenian wants United.
It is believed that RB Leipzig's talisman understands Newcastle can offer him Champions League football but he wishes to move to Old Trafford.
In contrast to the reports from Tuesday, United are claimed to have opened talks to sign Donnarumma this summer.
Sports Zone understands that United have contacted PSG over the availability of the goalkeeper.
This comes as PSG have made progress to sign Lille’s Lucas Chevalier recently.
Sadly for fans hoping that United would be able to bring him in, it seems Donnarumma's move to Old Trafford could be a non-starter.
According to Fabrizio Romano in his GiveMeSport column, the Italian is not currently on United's list of potential targets.
Romano claims that no contact has been made but the Reds are considering signing a new goalkeeper.
Hello and welcome back to the United transfer blog this Wednesday afternoon.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be taking you through the next four hours of United news and gossip.
First off, we are going to start with the latest on this man...
Wayne Rooney believes the next few weeks of the transfer window are huge for United.
Rooney has told the Belfast Telegraph:
I think it’s a huge few weeks before the start of the Premier League to see if they can get any more players in, what players they can get in, and players out as well – probably more importantly.
Antony has reportedly rejected two offers due to wanting a Real Betis return.

Spanish sports newspaper Estadio Deportivo [via Sport Witness] claims the winger does not want to stay in the Premier League despite reputed interest from Newcastle United and Nottingham Forest. Antony is also said to want a move still within Europe.

headline: LUCKHURST: Manchester United coach Ruben Amorim speaks out on Rasmus Hojlund future amid Benjamin Sesko interest
body: Ruben Amorim admits he does not know if Rasmus Hojlund is certain to stay at Manchester United amid their interest in striker Benjamin Sesko.
Hojlund scored United's opening goal in their 4-1 thrashing of Bournemouth in Chicago and tried to claim a second after Amad's shot appeared to deflect in off the Dane.

The 22-year-old's contribution came hours after it emerged United were advancing with a move for RB Leipzig goalscorer Sesko, having considered moves for Liam Delap, Viktor Gyokeres and Ollie Watkins earlier this summer.
United bought Hojlund from Atalanta in a £72million deal in July 2023 but he managed only four Premier League goals last term.
"The important thing is that people focus on the goals and we suffer a lot because of the lack of goals," Amorim said. "But I think not just the goals, but the way he (Hojlund) connects the play.

"Every time we have to kick the ball, we are kicking the ball when we are more pressed. The ability for him to hold the defender and to connect in the support is helping us a lot to play better. And we are playing better because he is playing better.

"I am really happy with Rasmus. I don't know what is going to happen until the end of the market. The important thing is that the strikers that are here are working really well, are improving, are helping the team and that is the most important thing.
"The important thing is that Rasmus is scoring goals. He's connecting really well with the team. He's improving. Again, I don't know what is going to happen until the market is closed."
United have won both of their Premier League Summer Series games in the States and their tour ends against Everton in Atlanta on Sunday.

Bournemouth are unbeaten against United in their past four Premier League matches but were soundly beaten at Soldier Field, where Patrick Dorgu and substitute Ethan Williams netted their first senior goals for United.
"I think it was a good game," Amorim added. "I think we played with intensity. We were aggressive and that is something that we need to improve on in the last season.

"I think we had better possessions compared to the last game, so they are listening. Of course, scoring first in the beginning of the game can change the confidence of the team. We changed some positions and you feel that they know what to do in different positions. It was a good test.
"We controlled quite well the runs of Evanilson, (Antoine) Semenyo. One against one. Luke Shaw was also really strong. It was a good day.

"It was just a pre-season game but the feeling with the same players, even being a pre-season game, if you look at the same players now playing, it looks like a different team and that is a good sign."

headline: Man United's new Alejandro Garnacho decision rests on Benjamin Sesko transfer
body: The success of Manchester United's summer transfer window will not solely be judged by the players they bring into the club but the ones they sell and, crucially, the amount received for them.

Marcus Rashford's exit to Barcelona seemed inevitable and while a loan deal was not ideal, it did manage to get a high earner off the wage bill. Despite Rashford's departure being a good start, there are still four players remaining at the club who want out.

Antony, Jadon Sancho, Tyrell Malacia and, crucially, Alejandro Garnacho are awaiting a new start that has yet to arrive. The latter's future is so crucial because of the pure profit value his sale would represent.

Garnacho was bought for a minimal fee and thus, United would bank nearly the entirety of his eventual transfer sum in the form of profit. That money can then be used to fund their transfer ambitions for the remainder of the window - chief of which is signing Benjamin Sesko from RB Leipzig.

The difficulty for United is that Garnacho has narrowed down the pool of clubs he would be happy to join. His ambition is to remain in the Premier League, understandably. Unfortunately for him, Chelsea are the only club who seem to be showing genuine interest.

One route to completing that transfer has now been closed off though. MEN Sport understands that United have no interest in entertaining a swap deal which would see Nicolas Jackson arrive at Old Trafford while Garnacho would go in the opposite direction to Chelsea.

On the face of things, this is a wise idea. Jackson has not set the world alight at Stamford Bridge and United sure do not need another striker who is struggling to find his feet in the Premier League.

However, the true success of this decision shall be measured, and ultimately rests entirely on, the ability to bring Sesko to United. If the Slovenian does not arrive in the summer window, the Reds shall remain without a new centre-forward and will have to rely on Rasmus Hojlund to lead the line again.
It is unclear whether or not Jackson would be an upgrade on Hojlund but the Reds are clearly going down the Sesko route so they must now get the job done and bring him to Old Trafford.

headline: LUCKHURST: Benjamin Sesko is a risk Manchester United may have to take
body: There was an inevitability that Manchester United would return to Benjamin Sesko's door.
Liam Delap chose Chelsea, Viktor Gyokeres wanted Arsenal, Alexander Isak is out of their reach and Aston Villa are digging their heels in over Ollie Watkins.

Sesko would be the biggest risk of the lot. He was born in 2003, played in Austria and has an underwhelming goalscoring record in one of Europe's top five leagues. That sounds familiar. The 22-year-old Sesko is actually younger than Rasmus Hojlund.

When United explored the possibility of signing Sesko in 2022, it was as one for the future. They effectively settled with that profile for Hojlund a year later, albeit as a starter. Pairing them does not add up.

Hojlund would likely have to make way if Sesko comes in. There is an argument that United should actually keep Hojlund and seek a buyer for Joshua Zirkzee, more affordable, not an out-and-out striker and with a marginally higher stock after a respectable calendar year.

But the noises from the United hierarchy about Hojlund are so damning that his card is marked. He is also part of the old regime, signed in dubious circumstances when he switched to the same agent as Erik ten Hag on the eve of his £72million transfer in July 2023.

Sesko could command a higher fee. United sources promised they would only sign Bryan Mbeumo for a "sensible" fee. £65million for a proven Premier League forward with 20 league goals last season just about qualified. Delap had a £30m release clause.

Sesko has played one club game in England and that was nearly three years ago. He does not have a record that justifies his reputed £79m value: 27 goals in 64 Bundesliga games for RB Leipzig. United baulked at the £30m Red Bull Salzburg demanded for Sesko in 2022.

He would have a senior support cast to ease the burden: Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha, Bruno Fernandes, Amad, Kobbie Mainoo et al. But a United striker is judged on goals and Sesko would be entering a team reeling from its worst season in 51 years.

Leipzig finished seventh in the Bundesliga last season. United are targeting a top-six finish in the Premier League. European qualification is essential, at the very least. Sesko would need broad shoulders.

United are starting to scramble around for that new No.9. Sesko is a similar profile to Delap in that they were born three months apart and he has potentially excellent attributes. The crucial difference is, unlike Mbeumo and Cunha, he has no Premier League experience.

"You can understand if you look at our team last year, we need also experience," Ruben Amorim cautioned. "Young players, because Matheus is young, still, but with experience. And then you watch every weekend, Matheus doing things against the players that you are going to face, that can help you to have more certainty when you choose players.

"So that was a policy that we tried to use this season. So I can say yes. It's not just that, because they have characteristics that we need, but we focus on getting players that can come here, and to face this kind of pressure, like you said, since the first day."

Sesko's agent, Elvis Basanovic, has been a guest of United's at Carrington and Old Trafford on multiple occasions since his client rejected the club three years ago. This time, Sesko could be at United's door.

headline: Manchester United vs Bournemouth highlights and reaction as Hojlund, Dorgu, Amad and Williams score
body: Manchester United made it two wins out of two in the Premier League Summer Series with a 4-1 win over Bournemouth at Soldier Field in Chicago.

Goals either side of half-time from Rasmus Hojlund, Patrick Dorgu, Amad and substitute Ethan Williams sealed a commanding victory for the Reds, who produced another really encouraging pre-season performance.

Just as they did against West Ham United in New Jersey last weekend, United started with a spring in their step, getting their noses in front after just eight minutes when Hojlund headed in Dorgu's cross.

The wing-back then scored a goal of his own just under 20 minutes later, latching onto a quick free-kick from Mason Mount. Amad increased United's lead not long after half-time, tucking the ball home from close range, before Williams buried a fine finish immediately after coming off the bench.
Bournemouth pulled a goal back very late on when Matthijs de Ligt turned the ball into his own net.
Head coach Ruben Amorim used 21 players against the Cherries, with only goalkeeper Tom Heaton playing the full 90 minutes.
United will conclude their pre-season tour of the United States against Everton at the Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta on Sunday.

headline: LUCKHURST: Ruben Amorim explains why Manchester United are a 'different team'
body: Ruben Amorim believes Manchester United look a "different team" and their intensity is "completely different" from last season.
United thrashed Bournemouth 4-1 in their second Premier League Summer Series match in Chicago, where Rasmus Hojlund scored twice and Patrick Dorgu and Ethan Williams netted.

Amorim picked a team devoid of either of United's senior summer signings as Matheus Cunha missed out due to fatigue. Bryan Mbeumo is scheduled to make his first appearance against Everton in Atlanta on Sunday.
There were six changes to the side that beat West Ham United 2-1 in New Jersey on Saturday and Amorim is especially encouraged by United's performance level.
"More than the results, it's the way they are playing," Amorim stressed. "I think it's really important. People cannot see that.
"I think they are playing better also because they are connecting better with each other. Not just on the pitch, but off the pitch. I think they are stronger, they are faster.
"In this moment, of course, it's a pre-season. But you can see the intensity is completely different. I can see the data from the minutes are completely different. So we are improving.

"But again, it's a pre-season game. The pressure is going to be so much different during the season. It's important for them to understand that the same players can play a different game. I think today was a good day.
"I'm really happy with the players that we had last season. They are improving. We look like a different team today. Let's continue with that."

Amorim also reserved praise for second-half substitute Diego Leon. Leon, 18, completed his transfer from Cerro Porteno at the start of the month and is set to provide cover for Dorgu on the left wing.
"I'm really happy with Bryan, Matheus, even Diego," Amorim added. "You can see it. He's a smart guy. He's a guy that came from Paraguay to come to the Premier League.
"He's really powerful, so I'm really happy with the three guys."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund Man United exit latest - Ruben Amorim admission, transfer stance, Serie A return
body: Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund is firmly in the spotlight on Thursday morning after his goal against AFC Bournemouth in the 4-1 pre-season victory.

The Dane opened the scoring inside eight minutes as his glancing header from Patrick Dorgu's cross set United on their way. His goal was crucial in more ways than one, considering hours earlier, the news broke that the Reds are advancing in their pursuit of RB Leipzig centre-forward Benjamin Sesko.

Should the Slovenian arrive, it is expected that he will be the first choice leaving Hojlund's role at the club potentially in danger. With this in mind, MEN Sport has rounded up the latest news surrounding the striker.

Speaking after the victory against Bournemouth, Amorim explained that he was unsure whether Hojlund's future was at Old Trafford or not. "I am really happy with Rasmus," the Portuguese head coach admitted.

"I don't know what is going to happen until the end of the market. The important thing is that the strikers that are here are working really well, are improving, are helping the team and that is the most important thing.
"The important thing is that Rasmus is scoring goals. He's connecting really well with the team.
"He's improving. Again, I don't know what is going to happen until the market is closed."

Despite the United boss being unsure whether Hojlund's future is in Manchester, the striker has always expressed his desire to stay at the club. Speaking last month while on international duty, the Dane told Bold his stance on staying at United.

"I have a contract until 2030, so I expect to play for Manchester United," he declared. "I’m looking forward to going on a summer vacation, and then I’m fully dedicated to the project that’s underway.
"As I’ve told you before, I try to stay away from all that [speculation], because it’s both for better and for worse these days."

If he were to leave this summer, Hojlund's likely destination would be Italy and a return to Serie A. Last week, Calciomercato claimed that United were now open to allowing their forward to leave on loan this summer.

headline: Benjamin Sesko starts, £30m exit sealed, Mbeumo role - Man United's new dream attack
body: Sport Central Audience Writer
Manchester United are advancing with a potential move for RB Leipzig's Benjamin Sesko. Ruben Amorim's side are in the market for a new No.9 and Sesko, 22, has emerged as their preferred option.

Ollie Watkins had been considered, but Aston Villa remain insistent that the England international is not for sale. Indeed, United have shifted their focus to Sesko, who scored 21 goals in 45 matches last season.

Sesko signed a five-year contract at Leipzig last summer and his new deal came with the understanding that if an elite club - by his definition - offered in the region of £69million to £78m, the German side would allow him to leave.

If United sign Sesko, he would complete a 'dream' front three and attacking line-up for Ruben Amorim next season. The former Red Bull Salzburg forward would come in and lead the line with Rasmus Hojlund acting as the back-up.
Behind Sesko would be the two attacking midfielders in Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system. First, Matheus Cunha would slot into the left No.10 position following his £62.5m move from Wolves last month.
Cunha, 26, netted 17 times and provided six assists in 36 appearances for Vitor Pereira's side in 2024/25 and is going to bring some more attacking flair and creative spark to United's front line.
Alongside Cunha in the right No.10 position would be another new signing, this time Bryan Mbeumo after he completed a £65m plus add-ons move to Old Trafford earlier this month.
Mbeumo, 25, found the net on 20 occasions and added nine assists in 42 matches for Brentford last season and would add some proven Premier League class, like Cunha, to United's attack.
Bruno Fernandes therefore would drop back into central midfield alongside one of Casemiro, Manuel Ugarte or Kobbie Mainoo. Patrick Dorgu and Amad Diallo would be used as the two wing-backs.
With Sesko, Cunha and Mbeumo as United's new-look dream front three, Hojlund, Joshua Zirkzee and Mason Mount would provide support from the bench and come in when required.

That would leave Alejandro Garnacho, Antony and Jadon Sancho to be sold before the end of the summer transfer window. It was reported on Tuesday that United were willing to sell Garnacho for around £30m, while Antony and Sancho are expected to depart the Reds in the coming weeks.

headline: Manchester United confirm new appointment after criticism from Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United have confirmed the appointment of two senior staff members.

Mike Sansoni has joined the club as director of data, following 11 years with the Mercedes F1 team. He will report to Omar Berrada and will 'transform the club’s capabilities in data and artificial intelligence'.

Sansoni was previously the senior performance engineer at Mercedes and contributed to eight world championship-winning seasons. United have announced that Sansoni will be tasked with establishing the club as a data-led organisation, embedding predictive and AI-driven decision-making.

In an interview with the United We Stand magazine in December, Sir Jim Ratcliffe slammed the data department at Old Trafford. “Until we are as good as anyone in the world, then it’s not good enough for Manchester United. We must have the best recruitment in the world," said Ratcliffe.

"Data analysis comes alongside recruitment. It doesn’t really exist here. We’re still in the last century on data analysis here. There’s immense amount of useful data that we can get from data analysis and we’re in the 'very poor' bracket with data analysis here. These things don’t happen overnight.
“You can’t just flick a light switch and sort out recruitment. It’s all about people and we need to find the right people.”
Sansoni will be supported by further appointments, with United announcing further recruitment is planned into a number of data, software and platform engineering roles in the coming months.
United have also confirmed the appointment of Kirstin Furberas as people director, a role in which Furberas will 'take the lead in developing and evolving the club’s workforce and people culture'.

Furberas is set to join United in the autumn following five years in the same role at Channel 4. She had previous spells with BBC Worldwide and 20th Century Fox, and has experience in sport as a non-executive director of British Wheelchair Basketball and previously at the London Football Association.

MEN Sport understands that Sesko is the priority for United this summer as they look to strengthen their attack. Aston Villa are adamant that Ollie Watkins is not for sale and at the risk of being drawn into another lengthy battle, they have decided to pivot to the Slovenian.

The 22-year-old has previously been compared to Erling Haaland due to his profile and similar routes in professional football. With RB Leipzig having missed out on the Champions League, it seemed only a matter of time before Sesko was set to leave and a gentleman's agreement between the player, his agent and the club could allow him to depart for as little as £69m.

Earlier in the window, Sesko was linked with a number of clubs including Arsenal and Al Hilal. But the forward was given a firm warning by his international manager not to move to the Middle East at this stage of his career.
Speaking to the media in June, Kek said: "Benjamin Sesko and Saudi Arabia? I would advise him to never go there.
"At least not at his age. This [the interest] is a great recognition, these are clubs that mean a lot.

"It's not that I underestimate the Saudi Arabia league, on the contrary, I worked there at Al Ittihad and the club is still a part of me. I also watch the league regularly but the time will come for Sesko for that.

"I am convinced that Benjamin himself and the people who care for him will be smart enough to find a solution. And that is for him to go somewhere where he can play football, because that is the only way he can be happy."
Such a solution looks to be forthcoming in the form of United and if they pull this off, it will be seen as a major coup for the Reds.

headline: Amad switch, Cunha decision, new back three - Manchester United predicted XI vs Bournemouth
body: Ross joined the MEN in August 2021. He was appointed Sport Content Editor in February 2022.
Manchester United will be looking to build on an impressive start to their pre-season tour when they face Bournemouth (2:30am kick-off UK time).

Amad started at right wing-back against West Ham and there's a chance that could be his settled position moving forward. headline: Why Manchester United have ruled Bryan Mbeumo out of Bournemouth fixture
body: Bryan Mbeumo is getting up to speed with his fitness and so is not involved against Bournemouth.
Manchester United playing their second game of the Premier League Summer Series in Chicago, but new signing Mbeumo was ruled out of the game by Ruben Amorim last week.

United signed Mbeumo from Brentford in time for him to travel to the US for the pre-season tour, but he was absent from the squad against West Ham in New Jersey due to his late arrival from Brentford.

When asked by MUTV for an update on Mbeumo, Ruben Amorim said: "He is not going to play the next one (vs Bournemouth). We hope to have Bryan in the last game (vs Everton). He is training now, so we will see."
United will end their visit to the States against Everton at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta on August 3, and Amorim confirmed Mbeumo has been earmarked to feature in that game.
Mbeumo is playing catch-up as Brentford started pre-season training a week after United. Mbeumo reported on day one but only did gym work to avoid the risk of injury amid his desire to join United.

Speaking to journalists on tour, Mbeumo said: "Manchester is a big club. I think it’s a great opportunity and I chose the project. I think I'm someone who likes a challenge. There is a very good project in Manchester and I wanted to be part of it.

"Of course, I spoke to some other managers because I wanted to hear their projects but the Manchester United one was very good for me. He (Amorim) said ‘we are people who like winning, and we want to be the best team’, and of course that's what we will try to do.
"I think it was a very friendly conversation and a constructive one. He explained his project to me, what he wanted to do and I really clicked on that.
"You want to play on the greatest stages in the world. And Old Trafford is one of them. So being able to play here every two weeks is just big."

headline: Ruben Amorim hints at no further Man Utd transfers with ‘really happy’ claim
body: Ruben Amorim has hinted Man Utd may do no further business in the striker transfer market despite being heavily linked with Ollie Watkins and Benjamin Sesko.

Just 44 goals last season, a tally only worsened by the relegated clubs and Everton, had every Man Utd fan crying out for new signings and while the club have already landed Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha, there is still a desire to sign an out-and-out number nine.
Aston Villa’s Watkins and RB Leipzig’s Sesko are thought to be the leading candidates but head coach Amroim has hinted the club may stick with their current options, most notably Rasmus Hojlund.
“I’m really happy with Rasmus,” Amorim said after his side beat Bournemouth 4-1 in Chicago.

“I don’t know what is going to happen until the end of the market. The important thing is that the strikers that are here are working really well, are improving, are helping the team and that is the most important thing.”
Amorim also said that while goals have been a problem for the Dane, he helps the team in other areas such as holding the ball up and bringing others into play.
“People focus on the goals and we suffer a lot because of the lack of goals,” Amorim said.
“I think not just the goals, but the way he connects the play every time we have to kick the ball.
“The ability for him to hold the defender and to connect in support is helping us a lot to play better and we are playing better because he’s playing better.”
But while the United board focuses on signings, Amorim was pleased with his side’s latest pre-season victory.
The Red Devils have won both of their Premier League Summer Series fixtures so far and top the group.

“It was a good game. We played with intensity. We were aggressive and that is something that we need to improve from last season,” said Amorim. “We had better possession compared to the last game, so they are listening.
“Of course, scoring first in the beginning of the games can change the confidence of the team. We changed some positions and you feel that they know what to do in different positions.
“It was a good test. We controlled quite well the runs of Evanilson and Semenyo one against one. Luke Shaw was also really strong. So it was a good day.

“It was just a pre-season game but the feeling with the same players, even being a pre-season game, if you look at the same players now playing, it looks like a different team and that is a good sign.”

“I think there is a crucial point here. We always see Newcastle signing many players, bringing top players to the club, but it’s difficult to see Newcastle selling players,” Romano said on the Men in Blazers podcast.

headline: Wayne Rooney ‘work ethic’ questioned in Tom Brady ‘lazy and entitled’ assessment
body: Wayne Rooney’s work ethic has been questioned by his former boss Tom Brady who also said the Birmingham squad was “lazy and entitled.”
The NFL Hall of Famer co-owns the Blues and his damning assessment has been revealed as part of a new Amazon Prime documentary set to air on Friday.
Brady questioned Rooney’s work ethic before passing judgment on a Birmingham squad that was relegated to League One in 2024.
“I’m a little worried about our head coach’s work ethic,” he said, as per the BBC. “I mean, I don’t know, I don’t have great instincts on that.”
Rooney’s time at Birmingham was difficult from the off having replaced John Eustace who had the Blues sixth in the Championship.
Rooney lost his first game, against former team-mate Michael Carrick, and had to wait until late November for his first win.
The England forward was then given the sack in January having picked up just two wins in 15 games and with the club in 20th.
As for the players, Brady blamed them for Birmingham’s relegation, suggesting they did not put in enough effort to stay up.
“Well we’ve already changed the coach, so it’s really the players because the coach doesn’t go out there and put the ball in the goal,” he said.
“They were lazy, they were entitled and when you’re lazy and entitled, you don’t have much of a chance to succeed.
“We’ve got to change all the people that are associated with losing, so I think this summer there’s going to be a lot of people gone.”
Another scene shows Rooney and Brady discussing the team’s plight with the former Man Utd striker suggesting it was a concentration issue.
“Why they’re playing in the Championship and not the Premier League,” Rooney said, “is because… we’ve all passed a ball, kicked the ball and run, but it’s a focus, concentrated for 90 minutes.”
Brady did at least admit some blame, suggesting the new ownership changed too much, too quickly.
“There was some good advice that I got that was like, ‘listen, don’t go in there and make these big, sweeping changes – you guys have time’,” he said.
“And of course we make sweeping changes.”

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Man Utd eye Man City keeper while arguing over strikers
body: Manchester United need to decide among themselves which striker they want, but they have been in touch with their neighbours to ask about a goalkeeper…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🆕 Stefan Ortega – Manchester City to Manchester United
The story goes that United have enquired about Ortega now he’s been relegated to third choice at City by James Trafford’s arrival. That’s as far as it has gone, and as far as it is ever likely to.

19) 🆕 Darwin Nunez – Liverpool to Juventus
The Old Lady are the latest to throw their hat in the ring for Nunez, who was previously a target for Napoli. Liverpool have been keen to sell the Uruguayan striker for a while, but they are even more eager now that Alexander Isak is available. It doesn’t alter the fact that neither Juve nor Milan can afford what Liverpool are hoping to get.

18) 🔼 Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
Football Insider’s Mick Brown is hearing things again, folks. Guehi to Liverpool could accelerate following Luis Diaz’s transfer to Bayern, apparently. The Crystal Palace captain’s “heart is set” on a move to Anfield, says the ex-Manchester United chief scout, who remains very well-connected within the game. FI’s words, not ours.

17) 🆕 Leandro Trossard – Arsenal to Borussia Dortmund
The Gunners man is on Dortmund’s list of winger targets, with Jadon Sancho also under consideration. Arsenal could reinvest some of the money into Rodrygo, which means their supporters are bang up for this.

16) 🆕 Gianluigi Donnarumma – PSG to Manchester United
Donnarumma has been in a contract dispute with PSG but we’re starting to think there might be more to this than his representatives using United’s name and the oldest trick in agent’s book. PSG are signing Lucas Chevalier from Lille and appear more likely to sell Donnarumma now than allow him to leave for nothing next year. United certainly need a goalkeeper, but they also need a striker and neither can be paid for with brass buttons. Still, one to watch…

15) 🆕 Samu Aghehowa – Porto to Aston Villa
The Spain international has also been linked with Newcastle but it’s Villa being mentioned as a potential destination for Aghehowa. One problem: Porto are using the Viktor Gyokeres fee as a benchmark and they want £55million. Which is more a less one whole Ollie Watkins.

14) Joao Palhinha – Bayern Munich to Tottenham
Spurs are looking for a new no.6 and while Conor Gallagher has been mentioned, there is greater clamour around Palhinha, who has been told he can leave Bayern after one season. Bayern want £30million; Spurs are chasing a discount. If they get one, and Palhinha still has some of the Fulham magic left, it would be a snip.

13) 🔼 Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Aston Villa 
United are said to have spoken to Chelsea and Villa in an effort to lump Garnacho in as part of a deal to sign a striker. Chelsea’s valuations of Garnacho and Nicolas Jackson are miles apart, but there could be some common ground with Villa. For the purposes of PSR, they would need to be separate transactions, but Villa are in a stronger position than United given they know Garnacho has got to go somewhere before the deadline, whereas they would be quite content to keep Watkins. Regardless, there is a deal to be done here.

12) Dominic Calvert-Lewin – Everton to Aston Villa
Calvert-Lewin left Everton at the end of last season and Villa reportedly see the ex-England striker as a cheap way to bolster their attacking options. Newcastle and AC Milan are thinking along similar lines but Villa currently appear to be favourites.

11) James McAtee – Manchester City to Nottingham Forest 
Forest are said to have had a bid rejected for the England Under-21 star, whose minutes at City are threatened by Rayan Cherki’s arrival. McAtee has interest from Eintracht Frankfurt and Borussia Dortmund, while Palace are keen too. But Forest aren’t far off with their £25million bid. We suspect this will come down to the player’s preference: stay in the Premier League, or a gap season or two in Europe?

10) 🔼 Yoane Wissa – Brentford to Newcastle
Newcastle are having a ‘mare of a summer, but some rare good news came in the form of Wissa’s desire to move to St James’ Park. However, and quite reasonably, we’ll add, Brentford are intent on keeping the forward having already lost their manager, captain and best player this summer. If Newcastle really want Wissa, they’ll have to pay over £40m for a player who was reportedly told last summer that he could leave for £26m at the end of 2024/25, prompting him to go on strike. With Brentford due back in London from their pre-season camp, we can expect some clarity here soon. The Bees have shown they are no pushover but Wissa isn’t f***ing around either.

9) Jadon Sancho – Manchester United to Juventus
It was reported ages ago that agreements had been reached between the clubs and the player, but still we wait. The reason, we suspect, is Juve stalling for time. They do need to sell, but they also know there is no other market for Sancho, If they sit tight, United will grow more desperate, as might the player, and better terms will almost certainly become available. Indeed, United’s price has come down again to between £15million and £17million (so, £16million?) and Sancho’s agent was in Turin last week in a vain attempt to speed things along.

8) 🔼 Ollie Watkins – Aston Villa to Manchester United
This one picked up again after reports that United are to choose between Watkins and Benjamin Sesko. Of course, we’d expect Villa might want a say in that. And, if asked, they’d say they want £60million. United, apparently, reckon they can get Villa down to around £45million. But they thought they could haggle with Brentford and ended up paying more for Bryan Mbeumo. Watkins might find himself as United’s preferred option just because they could offer Garnacho to Villa.

7) 🔼 Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Manchester United
On Wednesday morning, we were told that Watkins was the priority; by Wednesday evening, it’s Sesko. As always, it seems United are fighting themselves, with some lobbying for Watkins, while head of recruitment Christopher Vivell is pushing for the player he’s credited with signing for RB Leipzig six years ago. Has anyone asked Ruben Amorim?

6) Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Newcastle
If Newcastle get a massive fee for Isak, you can bet any discount Leipzig were offering on Sesko will be voided. Let’s say the Toon get £120million for Isak and they spend £75million on Sesko and cover the Anthony Elanga fee. Is that so terrible? Regardless, Newcastle’s interest in Sesko goes back a year and some reports suggest personal terms are already sorted. But Man Utd’s interest complicates matters. The worst-case summer scenario for Newcastle could become a grim reality.

5) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Viktor Gyokeres is signed, sealed and delivered and the feeling during that saga was that Eze would be the Gunners’ next target. The England star has, apparently, been telling his mates he’s moving to the Emirates, but Arsenal now need to deliver on Palace’s clear demand for his £68million buy-out clause to be met. Cue Andrea Berta haggling for weeks over the number of instalments. And the Gunners need to sell first.

4) Alexander Isak – Newcastle to Liverpool
Newcastle and Liverpool are currently at a stand-off, with Isak in the middle. Newcastle have received no bid yet, and the Reds are holding fire, knowing that time only increases the pressure on the Magpies. They are still intent on digging in, even if it means convincing Isak to stay for one more season, and are unlikely to sanction a sale without having a replacement sorted first. Sesko is their top target, but Man United are also there.. Given Isak left it so late to declare his wishes and Liverpool have already signed a striker in his place, it is easy to imagine this being kicked down the road until next summer. headline: Liverpool 2) and 7) in top 11(?!) best Premier League transfer windows ever
body: Liverpool are in the process of what many believe to be the transfer window of all transfer windows in the Premier League era to bolster a title-winning squad. But how does it rank among other excellent summer offerings?

A whimsical, some would say pointless, question that absolutely cannot be answered now before those new Liverpool players have kicked a ball for Liverpool, but that’s not stopped the Premier League website from setting a poll for biased fans of major clubs to torpedo and render almost entirely uninteresting, nor us from reordering said list of windows into the unimpeachable top 11 (why 11? don’t know).
We’ve included the percentages from the poll, which has predictably seen the 2025/2026 windows of two clubs voted for more than the other eight options combined…

11) Arsenal: 2025/2026 (14%)
Notable signings: Viktor Gyokeres, Martin Zubimendi, Noni Madueke, Kepa Arrizabalaga, Christian Norgaard

We wonder whether any of what we assume was a huge majority of Arsenal fans voting for this to rank as the second-greatest Premier League transfer window of all-time also signed the #NOTOMADUEKE petition a few weeks ago, or were #KROENKEOUT before signing the striker reported to be their second choice in favour of a guy who looks like he might join actual Manchester United.

10) Leicester: 2015/2016 (4%)
Notable signings: Shinji Okazaki, N’Golo Kante, Gokhan Inler, Robert Huth, Christian Fuchs
Funny this, because without Kante this window wouldn’t be in the top 50, and yet it’s absolutely deserving of a place here because they did sign him, for under £8m.

Okazaki, Huth and Fuchs all deserve their flowers for the key parts they played in the wonderful title win, but without meaning to be too harsh on those individuals, these being the signings made to push them from 14th to 1st does lend weight to the claim that Kante has had the greatest impact of any Premier League signing ever.

9) Chelsea: 2014/2015 (2%)
Notable signings: Diego Costa, Cesc Fabregas, Filipe Luis, Loic Remy, Didier Drogba

Both Costa and Fabregas were wonderful as Chelsea scampered to the title upon Jose Mourinho’s return, with Fabregas’ feeding of the menacing striker a particular avenue of success for a side with few weaknesses; graced by the return of a club legend in Drogba.

8) Wolves: 2018/19 (3%)
 Notable signings: Raul Jimenez, Rui Patricio, Adama Traore, Joao Moutinho, Diogo Jota, Willy Boly, Max Kilman, Leander Dendoncker

The Portuguese revolution began the year before, with super-agent Jorge Mendes’ mitts all over the the signing of Ruben Neves and appointment of Nuno Espírito Santo, who took Wolves to the Championship title having finished 15th the season before.

And in an ‘if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it’ but supercharge it sort of way, Mendes set about turning Molineux into the The Algarve of the West Midlands after promotion, somehow (by paying them lots of money) persuading Champions League-level footballers to join and push them to a quite extraordinary seventh-placed Premier League finish after six years away.

7) Liverpool: 2018/2019 (3%)
 Notable signings: Alisson, Naby Keita, Fabinho, Xherdan Shaqiri

We wonder if there’s been enough water under the bridge for Liverpool fans to accept that £53m Keita was not a misunderstood genius as the vast majority of them insisted was the case despite the swathes of evidence suggesting he was in fact a massive waste of money, but we guess not.

We reckon that has a lot to do with Michael Edwards getting nearly every other transfer right at this stage to set Liverpool up for success then and now, making it very difficult to accept any sort of failure on his part.
Alisson was deemed by many to be the missing cog which led Liverpool to their long-awaited title a year later, but the signing of Fabinho was also a stroke of genius.

6) Manchester City: 2015/2016 (4%)
Notable signings: Kevin De Bruyne, Raheem Sterling, Nicolas Otamendi, Fabian Delph

We might just have plumped for City’s 2017/2018 over this one, when Kyle Walker, Bernardo Silva, Ederson and Aymeric Laporte all arrived, but this was the summer when many a fan baulked at them paying a club-record £54m for a Chelsea flop who went on to become the greatest midfielder the Premier League has ever seen, as well as a mercurial Liverpool winger who then claimed 131 goals and 86 assists in 339 appearances.

5) Southampton: 2014/2015 (2%)
 Notable signings: Sadio Mane, Shane Long, Dusan Tadic, Fraser Forster, Graziano Pelle, Toby Alderweireld, Ryan Bertrand

This might just have come out on top had Virgil van Dijk been signed this summer rather than a year later, but there’s still a brilliant mix of talent and risk here, most of which paid off handsomely, not to mention one of the ultimate ‘streets won’t forget’ footballers in Pelle.

He got 16 goals in his debut season as the Saints finished seventh under Ronald Koeman, then sixth in 2015/2016 to qualify for the Europa League. All of Mane, Alderweireld and Tadic became Champions League stalwarts after leaving St Mary’s, while Bertrand and Forster made 240 and 162 Saints appearances respectively.

4) Manchester United: 2007/2008 (7%)
Notable signings: Anderson, Nani, Owen Hargreaves, Carlos Tevez, Tomasz Kuszczak

They joined the champions to create what many consider to be the greatest Manchester United squad – possibly the greatest squad of any team – in the Premier League era, with absurd quality and depth in almost all areas.

Kuszczak, Anderson and Nani were on the bench with Ryan Giggs, Mikael Silvestre, John O’Shea and Darren Fletcher as John Terry’s slip in Moscow handed them their second Champions League trophy, to go with the Premier League title they also pipped Chelsea to that season.

3) Manchester City: 2010/2011 (4%)
Notable signings: Yaya Toure, Mario Balotelli, David Silva, Aleksandar Kolarov, Jerome Boateng, James Milner

The signings which secured the first trophy of the Abu Dhabi era when Yaya Toure scored the only goal of the FA Cup final victory over Stoke City in 2011, before all of them – with the exception of Boateng – played a major role in their first and most dramatic Premier League title win a year later. You may just remember the trophy-clinching goal.

2) Liverpool: 2025/2026 (39%)
Notable signings: Jeremie Frimpong, Florian Wirtz, Milos Kerkez, Hugo Ekitike, Giorgi Mamardashvili

Again, we’re well aware how fatuous this is given they’re yet to play for Liverpool, but assuming they sign Marc Guehi or another top centre-back, we’re pretty confident this has indeed been an excellent transfer window for them; they would each have to perform quite significantly below expectations for it to not at least be a very good one.

Arne Slot, Richard Hughes and Michael Edwards have come up with the ingenious plan of identifying the spots in need of strengthening and signing their top targets in each of those positions – it will never catch on. And if Liverpool can break Newcastle and PIF’s resolve to sign Alexander Isak we fully expect them to run away with the league which they look destined to win again in any case.
READ: Wirtz, Cunha, Xhaka: Top 10 Premier League signings of the 2025 summer transfer window

1) Chelsea: 2004/2005 (13%)
Notable signings: Didier Drogba, Ricardo Carvalho, Paulo Ferreira, Arjen Robben, Tiago, Petr Cech, Mateja Kezman

They spent more money the summer before but their first opportunity to use the Roman Abramovich money was all a bit scattergun; they got their transfer eye in once their first big signing, arguably their most important signing ever – Jose Mourinho – got his feet under the table.

Carvalho and Ferreira were part of the most miserly back four in Premier League history, helping Cech to concede just 15 goals – a record unlikely to ever be beaten – with the goalkeeper consistently one of the best, if not the best, around for the next decade. Robben was close to unplayable in his all-too brief time at Stamford Bridge. And then there’s Drogba.

164 goals in 381 appearances may not put him in the top, top echelons of strikers, but his extraordinary record of nine goals in 10 cup finals more than makes up for that, with his 88th-minute header and winning penalty in the 2021 Champions League final his pièce de résistance.

headline: Wirtz, Cunha, Xhaka: Top 10 Premier League signings of the 2025 summer transfer window
body: Liverpool, Manchester United and Manchester City each have two players in our ranking of the top 10 Premier League signings of the summer transfer window.

10) Milos Kerkez (Liverpool)
We said ages ago that Liverpool needed a left-back. They listened, and here is Milos Kerkez for £40million – a decent price in this inflated market. While Andy Robertson will always be a cult hero and (at least) a two-time Premier League champion, he was a weak link in an otherwise slick Slot machine.

Kerkez is quicker, younger (22 in November), and frankly better. The Hungarian is an upgrade, and crucially, Premier League-proven. He and Jeremie Frimpong are both strong additions, but Kerkez edges it, partly because Frimpong might fall over if you breathe on him too hard.

9) Joao Pedro (Chelsea)
This one shot up the rankings after Pedro tore it up in the Club World Cup. He wouldn’t have made the cut otherwise, but those performances were outrageous. The brace against his boyhood club Fluminense left us in awe, and he didn’t stop there, scoring against PSG in the final as Chelsea smashed the European champions 3-0.
The Blues splashed £55million, which already doesn’t look like too much. They might finally have an elite No.9 that makes Enzo Maresca’s side serious Premier League title contenders.

8) Granit Xhaka (Sunderland)
This shouldn’t be happening, but it is. Sunderland, fresh off promotion, have convinced Granit Xhaka to swap Champions League football with Bayer Leverkusen for a relegation scrap. And we love it.

For just £13million, they’ve signed a player far too good for the bottom half. Sure, he’s had his critics – many of them loud and correct – but the Swiss international has matured, added composure, and now walks into this team as captain-in-waiting. Sunderland have watched Burnley, Ipswich and others make transfer mistakes and get relegated. They’re doing things a bit differently and we rate it highly.

7) Bryan Mbeumo (Manchester United)
There’s one glaring issue with this transfer: This Is Manchester United We’re Talking About. They have a habit of botching signings, no matter how brilliant the player was before taking the graveyard shift at Old Trafford.

We want to love this signing. Mbeumo fits Ruben Amorim’s system perfectly. But this club, man. If the ex-Brentford star ends 2025/26 with three goals after scoring 20 last term, we won’t be shocked. But for now, credit where it’s due. On paper, it’s an excellent deal.

6) Rayan Ait-Nouri (Manchester City)
Pep Guardiola has signalled a readiness to tweak his defensive set-up with the £31m signing of Ait-Nouri from Wolves. The Algerian international is more naturally a wing-back, but we’re confident in his ability to hold his own as an out-and-out full-back.

That’s the role he’ll play at Man City, especially after the left-back spot has been consistently filled by centre-backs. Guardiola’s rotation policy means Josko Gvardiol will still start games there, but his move to left-centre-back could be the most significant outcome of the Ait-Nouri signing.
The former Wolves man boasts 24 goal involvements in 135 Premier League appearances, and his attacking instincts certainly add an edge to a City side that underwhelmed in 2024/25.

5) Matheus Cunha (Manchester United)
Another great player that Manchester United might destroy. Cunha was exceptional for Wolves last season and now finds himself slotted perfectly into Amorim’s system as a left-sided ‘wide 10’.

He and Mbeumo offer something United have been lacking: actual output. Now they just need an elite centre-forward. If they get that piece, top-half football might actually be on the cards. High hopes, we know.
It’s hard to see Cunha struggling. He’s very, very good at football. But we do fear for him. Because, you know, lads, it’s Man United.
MAILBOX: Man Utd have signed another ‘knob-end’ in Mr Walky McWalkface

4) Caoimhin Kelleher (Brentford)
Another intra-Premier League move, Kelleher has finally left Liverpool to spread his wings as a top-flight No.1. As his ranking shows, this looks like an outstanding pick-up for Brentford, who replaced Mark Flekken superbly and sorted the goalkeeper spot early this summer.

Kelleher had to leave, especially with Giorgi Mamardashvili arriving, and considering how brilliant Liverpool are at flogging fringe players, we’re honestly stunned his initial fee is only £12.5million. It could rise to £18m, which is still a steal.

Selling him for half what Jarell Quansah cost Bayer Leverkusen probably sums up Liverpool’s weak stance in transfer talks. Kelleher wanted out, keeping him made little sense, and they weren’t d*cks about it. Brentford will be bloody chuffed.

3) Viktor Gyokeres (Arsenal)
Finally. Arsenal have signed a striker who isn’t terrified of the 18-yard box. Viktor Gyokeres has been smashing in goals for fun over the last three seasons – 22 in 50 for Coventry, 43 in 49 for Sporting, and then an obscene 54 in 52 last term.

Yes, it’s ‘only the Portuguese league’ and no, he’s not the next Bas Dost. Gyokeres has the strength, speed, work rate, and most importantly, finishing ability, to succeed in Our League. Arsenal now have a proper No.9. It’s about bloody time.

2) Tijjani Reijnders (Manchester City)
Nico Gonzalez didn’t automatically become the best midfielder in the world after his big-money January move, so Man City went out and signed Reijnders from a Milan side without Champions League football next season, and what a bloody signing he is.

The Dutchman’s arrival was necessary after Kevin De Bruyne’s departure, while Mateo Kovacic and Bernardo Silva are not getting any younger. Reijnders is a different type of midfielder to De Bruyne, but he brings an elite ability to carry the ball up the pitch and combines relentless energy with superb technical quality.
It’s hard to find a downside. City could be utterly unstoppable again in 2025/26.

1) Florian Wirtz (Liverpool)
A lot will be made of the £100m transfer fee Liverpool paid, and every single Florian Wirtz touch will be forensically analysed by people who’ve never seen him play before now. Because that’s what really matters – not that the Reds have signed one of the best attacking midfielders in the world, and someone who’s world-class at just 22.
The club-record fee was almost enough for Wirtz to drop a place or two here, but purely from a footballing perspective, this comfortably looks like the best signing of the summer…so far.

headline: Man Utd bid for Sesko ‘driven’ against Amorim’s will as Red Devils boss ‘prefers’ alternative
body: The Manchester United push to sign Benjamin Sesko ahead of Newcastle is not being ‘driven’ by Ruben Amorim, who ‘prefers’ an alternative.
United completed the signings of Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon early in the window before dragging their feet to get a deal for Bryan Mbeumo over the line.
A new striker is now their priority, with RB Leipzig’s Sesko emerging as their top target, though Ollie Watkins and Nicolas Jackson are still of interest to the Red Devils.
Newcastle have made the early running in the race to sign Sesko but now Man Utd have made their move to ‘open formal talks’ today in order to get a deal done.

Transfer expert Ben Jacobs wrote on X: ‘#MUFC open formal talks for Benjamin Sesko after sending a secret delegation to Germany. Christopher Vivell driving. Ruben Amorim put forward Ollie Watkins. #NUFC remain in the race. Both hoping price drops to €70m.’

Before The Athletic’s David Ornstein revealed that Man Utd are now ‘prioritising a move’ for Sesko with the journalist adding that ‘Alexander Isak wanting to leave St James’ Park’ has ‘accelerated the actions’ of the Red Devils to get a deal done.

Ornstein added: ‘Watkins has admirers at Old Trafford but Villa told United early in the window that the 29-year-old is not for sale and are adamant he is staying. The United hierarchy are reluctant to pay what they thought it may have taken for Villa to consider doing business.’
A report on Wednesday claimed that ‘the feeling inside Newcastle is that Sesko is likely to go to Manchester United’.

‘Newcastle are continuing to pursue deals for RB Leipzig’s Benjamin Sesko and Brentford’s Yoane Wissa. However, the feeling inside the club is that Sesko is likely to go to Manchester United, which would be a huge frustration given they are so keen on the Slovenian.

‘That, though, could potentially pave the way for a move for Aston Villa’s Ollie Watkins, who is on Newcastle’s shortlist. So is Chelsea’s Nicolas Jackson, but several others are ahead of him at present.’

Transfer expert Ben Jacobs confirmed in a talkSPORT report that United have indeed ‘opened talks for Sesko’ and have ‘sent a delegation to Germany to meet RB Leipzig officials’, with the 22-year-old ‘favouring a move to Old Trafford’.

Chief negotiator Matt Hargreaves ‘arrived a few days ago’ as United are ‘aware they have to move fast’ to beat Newcastle to the Slovenian, with both Premier League clubs ‘believing they can get a deal done for €70m [£60m].
It’s claimed the move for Sesko is being ‘driven’ by head of recruitment Christopher Vivell, with Amorim ‘preferring’ Aston Villa’s Ollie Watkins.
The report adds:
‘Sesko is one of two active options for Manchester United along with Aston Villa striker Ollie Watkins, though talkSPORT understands Ruben Amorim would prefer the latter.
‘Villa don’t wish to sell the England striker, but United may still persist with talks and even test that resolve with a bid.
‘They have not yet ruled out making a formal offer, albeit one below Villa’s £60m valuation.
‘There remains internal debate at United as to whether to opt for proven Premier League experience or a younger No.9 with a high ceiling such as Sesko.’

headline: Loser in Sesko race ‘set’ for £55m Bayern hijack as Man Utd, Newcastle ‘locked’ in second ‘battle’
body: Manchester United and Newcastle are ‘locked in a battle’ for an alternative to Benjamin Sesko in a possible Bayern Munich hijack.

After United lost out to Chelsea in the race for Liam Delap early in the window while Hugo Ekitike chose Liverpool over Newcastle before also turning Alexander Isak’s head, both clubs are still eager to land a new No.9.
Newcastle have made the early running in the race to sign Sesko but now Man Utd have made their move to ‘open formal talks’ today in order to get a deal done.

Transfer expert Ben Jacobs wrote on X: ‘#MUFC open formal talks for Benjamin Sesko after sending a secret delegation to Germany. Christopher Vivell driving. Ruben Amorim put forward Ollie Watkins. #NUFC remain in the race. Both hoping price drops to €70m.’

TBR Football claimed on Wednesday that ‘offers have been submitted’ for Sesko by both Man Utd and Newcastle, with chief correspondent Graeme Bailey revealing when the Slovenian is expected to decide his future, with a third option still an “unlikely” possibility.
“Personal terms are not an issue for either club, but the talks were based around the projects on offer in the North West and North East,” Bailey said.

“Now the decision is with Sesko, but it is believed he will confirm his decision before the weekend. There is the chance he decides to remain in Germany for another season, but that is now seen as unlikely.
“RB Leipzig gave permission to both clubs to hold talks with Sesko, who they have accepted can leave, as long as their terms are met.”

Reports suggest Sesko is leaning towards a move to Old Trafford, but in any case both the Magpies and Red Devils are considering alternatives, with The Sun claiming Stuttgart’s Nick Woltemade has emerged as an option for them.
‘United and Newcastle are set to be locked in ANOTHER transfer battle to land Woltemade as their next striker’, the report claims.
The 23-year-old looked set for Bayern Munich after agreeing terms with the Bundesliga champions, as reported by Sky Germany’s Florian Plettenberg over a month ago.
He wrote on X: ‘EXCLUSIVE | FC Bayern and Nick #Woltemade have reached a full verbal agreement on a summer transfer! The 23 y/o versatile striker wants to join Bayern with immediate effect.
‘Long-term contract until 2030 with salary terms already agreed in the last days. Bayern’s supervisory board have already approved the deal.
‘There have been no negotiations between the clubs yet. The contract with VfB is valid until 2028, with no release clause. VfB want to keep him.’

Bayern are said to have offered €40m [£34m] for Woltemade, but Stuttgart want €65m [£55m] for their prized asset, and The Sun claim Bayern ‘might pull out of the race’ after spending £56m to sign Luis Diaz from Liverpool, in a ‘boost’ to Newcastle and Man Utd’s ‘chances of landing him this summer.
Arsenal have entered ‘talks’ with Stuttgart over a move for their £42m striker as a possible alternative to Sesko, while Liverpool also hold ‘genuine interest’.

headline: Man Utd: Gary Neville reveals next signing INEOS ‘need’ to make in prediction for 25/26 season
body: Manchester United legend Gary Neville has revealed the next signing that the Premier League giants need to make after landing Bryan Mbeumo.

Mbeumo and Cunha are good signings for Man Utd, but they have loads of business still to do during this summer’s transfer window.

The lack of exits are impacting Ruben Amorim‘s side and limiting their business as Marcus Rashford is their only high-profile departure, while Antony, Alejandro Garnacho, Tyrell Malacia and Jadon Sancho remain contracted to the Premier League giants.
This is deterring pursuits for their remaining key targets, with reports indicating that their remaining priorities are a striker, a defensive midfielder and a goalkeeper.
Neville has commented on United’s business and picked out the signing they “need” next. He has also revealed his feelings on his former side’s prospects next season.

Daily Mail journalist Craig Hope wrote in his latest column: ‘Newcastle are continuing to pursue deals for RB Leipzig’s Benjamin Sesko and Brentford’s Yoane Wissa. ‘That, though, could potentially pave the way for a move for Aston Villa’s Ollie Watkins, who is on Newcastle’s shortlist. So is Chelsea’s Nicolas Jackson, but several others are ahead of him at present.’

Ferdinand continued: “I wanted a striker with experience so he wouldn’t be my first-choice, obviously, even now.

headline: Man Utd: New third kit stirs up memories of Cantona’s famous ‘kung fu’ kick against Palace
body: Manchester United are set to launch a third kit based on one of the most controversial moments in Premier League history.

Kit maker Adidas will release a black third shirt with white and blue trim for the Old Trafford side and it is eerily similar to the shirt worn by former United and France star Eric Cantona when he performed his famous ‘kung fu’ kick.

Cantona was banned for nine months for his infamous attack on a Crystal Palace supporter after he shouted abuse at Cantona. The United striker also received a two month prison sentence that was later reduced to community service, and a £30,000 fine for the incident.

The incident became footballing legend and Cantona’s nonsensical press conference where he talked about seagulls and trawlers only added to the intrigue around the mercurial striker. The black away shirt he wore that day became synonymous with Cantona and has become a cult favourite for United fans to this day.
READ: Premier League new home kits ranked from worst to Leeds United
Adidas will release the third kit on 12 August here and it plans to launch an entire Retro Collection range alongside the 2025/26 shirt.

The Retro Collection range is streetwear that Adidas launches alongside its ‘Elite’ clubs and United’s will include a black jacket and t-shirts in the same style as the black and yellow away kit from 1993 to 1995. The range will also feature a stripped back Manchester United badge featuring only the Red Devil logo.
The new third shirt and the Retro Collection will also feature Adidas’ Trefoil logo used in the 1980s on Adidas kits.

United remain one of Adidas’ biggest brands and joins the likes of Arsenal, Liverpool and Real Madrid at the top tier of the manufacturer’s ‘Elite’ brands. It means United get unique merchandise ranges, long-sleeved stadium shirts and worldwide distribution. Adidas will also launch dedicated United special edition products including trainers and one-off shirts throughout the season.

“To be honest, I don’t read the news but if another striker were to come I guess it’s only good competition so I’m not really worried.
“Everything is for the team, there’s no selfishness here, that’s not my mantra. If it were to help the team then great.”
The Netherlands international contributed seven goals and two assists in 49 appearances in all competitions last term and Zirkzee is looking to show his “best form” in the upcoming campaign.
Zirkzee added: “I don’t think I’ve shown my best form.
“I think I was on my way towards it [before his injury], but I think there’s improvement every day for all of us.
“[Amorim] wants goals so that’s what I have to work on. That’s what it all comes down to.

“I’m a different profile but in the end if you’re up top you’re supposed to score goals, I’m not going to take that fact away. But the most important thing is that we win so if Bruno scores 60 goals and we win all the games that’s fine.”

“So being able to play here every two weeks is just big.  When I spoke properly with the gaffer, he said “we are people who like winning, and we want to be the best team”, and of course that’s what we will try to do.
“We had a very friendly and constructive conversation. He explained his project to me, what he wanted to do and I really clicked on that.
